statement.text: Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) encompasses compression of the brachial plexus, subclavian artery, or subclavian vein in the thoracic outlet (between clavicle and first rib). It is classified into neurogenic TOS (95%), venous TOS/Paget-Schroetter (3-5%), and arterial TOS (1-2%). Each type has distinct presentation, diagnosis, and treatment approaches.
statement.formal: TOS Types: Neurogenic (95% - brachial plexus), Venous (3-5% - Paget-Schroetter, effort thrombosis), Arterial (1-2% - subclavian compression, aneurysm); All from thoracic outlet compression

explanation.intuition: The thoracic outlet is like a busy intersection where nerves, arteries, and veins all pass through a narrow space between the collarbone and first rib. If this space narrows (from an extra rib, tight muscles, or abnormal anatomy), structures get squeezed. Nerves are most sensitive to pressure (neurogenic TOS), but veins (Paget-Schroetter) and arteries can also be affected in more severe cases.
explanation.key_insight: The three types of TOS are distinct clinical entities requiring different approaches. Neurogenic TOS is common but controversial, often treated conservatively with physical therapy. Venous TOS presents acutely as arm DVT requiring thrombolysis and decompression. Arterial TOS is rare but serious, often presenting with distal embolization from subclavian aneurysm.
explanation.technical_details: Compression occurs in three spaces: interscalene triangle (between anterior and middle scalenes), costoclavicular space (between clavicle and first rib), and pectoralis minor space (under pectoralis minor tendon). Anatomic predispositions include cervical rib (0.5% population), elongated C7 transverse process, anomalous muscles, and previous clavicle fracture.

provocative_tests.adson_test: Turn head to affected side, extend neck, deep breath - positive if radial pulse diminishes
provocative_tests.east_test: Elevated arm stress test - arms abducted 90°, repeatedly make fists for 3 min
provocative_tests.costoclavicular_test: Pull shoulders back and down - positive if reproduces symptoms

surgical_approaches.transaxillary: First rib resection via axilla - good cosmesis, limited access
surgical_approaches.supraclavicular: Scalenectomy ± first rib resection - better for arterial TOS
surgical_approaches.infraclavicular: For venous TOS with residual stenosis - venolysis, patch

definition.@value: Compression of neurovascular structures in the thoracic outlet, classified as neurogenic, venous, or arterial based on affected structure

clinical_pearls: Neurogenic TOS = most common but most controversial diagnosis
Young athlete with sudden arm swelling = venous TOS (Paget-Schroetter) until proven otherwise
Arterial TOS often presents with emboli - check for subclavian aneurysm
First rib resection is the definitive decompression for all types

medicalCode.description: Acute embolism and thrombosis of subclavian vein (venous TOS)
